In the matter of credits for each show, Harley proposed that the phrase be
used, "This series is arranged or presented in cooperation with the staff
of...” It was understood that a consultant would appear on each show and that
that the names of all cooperating institutions would be used if possible.
This was agreed to.
Papp and Fuller joined the meeting at 1:00 P.M. They backed up Harley’s time
table of production on both the Jefferson and the USSR shows. (This had pre¬
viously been questioned by Probst who didn’t think they could move that fast.)
Fuller outlined some of the difficulties he is having in getting the shows
ready for production. He said that he was sure we were going to be subject
to attack. He thought that one way we could lessen the attack would be to
tie together the publicity on the.USSR and the Jefferson series. He also
thought, under questioning, that "insulation” whould be difficult. He was
sure" that Fisher (of Stanford) felt that the shows should all stand on their
own. Herbert Hoover was again suggested as the ideal kick-off man on the
series. Fuller thought Fisher could get him, but wasn’t sure he’d want to
do it. In McCarty’s absence, Harley again presented his idea that insulation
was not necessary and that we should let the shows stand or fall on the names
of the consultants. Papp thought that if we feel the need for insulation on
the USSR shows, we might also feel the need for it on the Jefferson show.
The general impression was that we should wait until we hear all the shows
and then decide on the need for insulation. Wheatley restated his position
that he felt it was our educational responsibility to do something about the
current hysteria regarding Russia. Probst and Siegel expressed their convic¬
tion that the auspices of a few leading Americans would be necessary, feasible,
and desirable for the Russian series.
Probst raised the possibility of sponsoring the USSR series by the Iron and
Steel Institute or Standard Oil of New Jersey—or other like concerns—on a
national commercial network. All committee members present liked the idea.
Harley said he was sure McCarty would vote against it. No vote was taken on
the matter. Harley, Papp, and Fuller all thought sponsorship would bring
complications to our working arrangements with both the consultants and the
institutions they represent.
The question of whether to do further shows on the USSR was raised. Fuller
thought that there was plenty of material, but that we should not continue
on the USSR alone. Maybe we should switch over to the general issue of in¬
ternational understanding. Papp thought we should continue shows on the USSR.
He felt that we would not suffer very much in the way of further attacks for
continuing the series, and that we did have a responsibility to educate.
Probst thought that we had gone through a costly process of acquainting the
consultants on how to develop good radio programs in this area and that it
would be economically wise to continue to use them. Further, we will have
only begun to touch the possible material in this field and we should recog¬
nize that everybody who knows about this project series in the FAE is very
enthusiastic about it.
